subject: San Diego
event:
Comicons have certainly changed a lot since I attended the very first one, back in 1963 in New York.  That one all took place in one room in a seedy Greenwich Village hotel.  The "dealer's room" was a couple of tables in the back of the panel room, where some of the organizers were selling their doubles out of cardboard boxes.

This year's San Diego Comicon pretty much filled up the entire city of San Diego.  Huge, overwhelming, exhausting, a bit scary... one runs out of adjectives.  The concom took very good care of me, however, and I had a great time signing, speaking, sweating (it was bloody HOT in San Diego), and tromping up and down the length of the San Diego Convention Center, past hundreds of booths and displays, a giant Lego Batman, and other sights too numerous to mention.  There was a very hot Wonder Woman wandering around one day, and an equally hot Mazda RX-8 on display at the Top Cow booth, both of which I lusted after, and I had the thrill of doing a panel with Peter S. Beagle, whose work I have admired for a long long time (if you have never read THE LAST UNICORN or A FINE AND PRIVATE PLACE, don't call yourself a fantasy fan).  

The parties were wild as well.  The posh Sci-Fi Channel party on the pool deck of the swank Solamar Hotel and the Conan party with its sword-swinging dancing girls were both great and the goth/ vampire bash X-sanguine was unforgettable.  An old abbey, stained glass windows, video screens, pillowed alcoves, and swarms of hot young women in leather and corsets... I could swear that I spent part of the evening talking with Jack Black, but I think that was just the drinks they kept thrusting into my hands.  

It wasn't all fun and games, however.  I had a lot of business meetings in San Diego as well, and a number of them are going to result in new deals and projects and comics and toys and other good stuff somewhere down the line, I hope... but I can't talk about any of that until the contracts are signed.

I also had a great brunch with some stalwarts from the Brotherhood Without Banners, who seem to be everywhere these days.  I hadn't enjoyed brunch at the Westgate since 1987 or so (it used to be the headquarters hotel for DC Comics, back when comicon was still in the old convention center next door), but it was just as fabulous as I remembered.

That's all the fun I will be having for a while, however.  I'm home again and it is time to get going on the novel once more.  I have less than a month until worldcon, and I would like to get a big chunk of DANCE done before I take off for Anaheim.

comments.article:
"I could swear that I spent part of the evening talking with Jack Black, but I think that was just the drinks they kept thrusting into my hands."

So it's possible you were talking with Jack Daniels and Johnnie Walker Black? Easy mistake to make :)

if you have never read THE LAST UNICORN
I saw the movie, does that count? Am I redeemed any by the fact that I wanted to name my daughter "Amalthea"?
Where did you see that picture???  I want a link!

...but I can't talk about any of that until the contracts are signed.

You obviously delight in driving us crazy, you tease!

comments.upictitle: All Flesh Must Be Eaten: Dead
comments.article:
This was my first year going to Comic-con and I was blown away by just how massive it all was.

I was also blown away by the fact that there weren't more COMIC BOOKS there.

:-\

You must have missed the giant section of tubs and tubs of comic books. :D  Though it's such a huge building, sometimes you find out about things later that you had NO CLUE were going on while you were there.
Glad you had fun for all of us who couldn't make it! :)

Man, we loved having you, and we're glad you had as much fun as we did. When my wife opened my wallet the next morning, she remarked, "wow, I spent all our money buying George drinks!"

Here's a great shot of you and some chick I toooooooooooooooooooooooooooootally don't know.
Well, who wouldn't!

Glad you had fun at Comicon!

As an Englishman, I'm suffering in this American heat... but I can hardly imagine San Diego this time of year... yuck.

Glad to hear the novel is coming along! I'm a new joiner here, and am currently deeply engrossed in A STORM OF SWORDS. I resent real life for getting in my way of reading it, in fact. And I find it very cool that you have an LJ so I can harass you with comments like this. So, er, good work!
What's the rush, after you're done, you will feel like and adict without his ....., so take your time and pray to god that it is not going to end.

I suppose that having always been something more of a sci-fi fan, I'm excused from having read the Last Unicorn at the present moment. ;-p

The bit about Jack Black cracked me up though.
New deals and projects involving comics?  I think I picked a great time to get back into comics!
Peter S. Beagle is amazing, but he's also in need of help (as I found out via sfandf_writers). Please check it out.

Conan party? /jealous Leather and corsets? /want

Also, the Lego booth is definitely neato -- last year had a Lego Yoda which was the object of my complete adoration.

Ooo... SoIaF toys? Could there be anything cooler?

comments.upictitle: Darth Paradox: Colette - Zounds (Return To Sender)
comments.article:
This was my first Comic-Con. And, well... holy crap, it was huge.

It was a lot of fun watching you on the fantasy panels. Thanks a lot!

(I suspect that Wonder Woman was the one with the actual metal breastplate and wristbands? You certainly weren't the only one noticing her...)

This was my first Comic-con too and what a fabulous time! I only got to attend Friday unfortunately, but I caught part of your panel (which I enjoyed immensely) as well as a few others. I then walked around in dumb awe at the amount of people, the displays in the exhibit hall, and the costumes. I missed Wonder Woman but I did see a fully painted, lovely Twi'lek!

Glad you had such a fun time at the convention. :D I need to check your schedule to see if you will be attending Dragoncon. Another first for me this year!
Toys? Ooooohhhh. <3

comments.upictitle: The Greatest Fucking Genius of All Time: villain
comments.article: It would be easier to list the pop culture references that that article doesn't mention.  That article is hilarious!

Have you seen the web site for the live action movie of The Last Unicorn?

The site used to be a little different:
http://www.the-last-unicorn.net/index.htm

But there it is!
that thing has been in pre-production for the longest time.  I've been following it through IMDB.com
Oh, I love The Last Unicorn! Man, I hope that movie comes out eventually.
I've had that movie for many many years.. so this comment makes no sense to me.

Hello, Mr. Martin. :)

I just wanted the chance to say that I really enjoy your series, I first read A Game of Thrones when I was twelve, after my father stuck in my hands. (Its no wonder why Arya, Jon and Bran have been constant favorites of mine, I was just about their ages then and I thought it was the neatest thing.) I know you get innumerable emails and comments from fans, but I just had to add my voice too. Its one of my favorite escapes, the world you've set and created within that series. Thank you, for all of it.

- Sara
sounds like it was a blast!

Glad you had a good time at the comic con! I plan to attend next year. Unfortunatly, you wont be at the Chicago comic-con hosted by wizard next week. I plan to be there. Maybe one day I will meet The Great GRRM! Maybe next year in July when you are in Indy.
DYING for Dance!
Sounds like a good time was had by all, although I am now left pondering who Jack Black could play in a ASoIaF adaption. And I hope work on ADWD continues to go well.
Tyrion.  shrink him a little and set him loose.
The last unicorn!!! Love.  The cartoon movie was my favorite when i was little, and then i discovered the book and it was maybe the best day of my life.
